question: Question_05
statement:
Let $f(x)=1+\frac{1}{x^2}$. Calculate $\displaystyle f'(x)$ using the
limit definition of the derivative. No credit will be given for other
methods of differentiation.
sols:
Using the limit defnition of the derivative we have

$f'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x + h) - f(x)}{h} =  \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{(1 + \frac{1}{(x+h)^2})- (1 + \frac1{x^2})}{h}$

To simplify, we cancel the ones in the numerator, find a common
denominator for the fractions, and simplify:

\begin{align*}
&= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{ \frac{x^2}{(x^2)(x+h)^2}- \frac{(x+h)^2}{x^2( x+h)^2}}{h} \\
&= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{ \frac{x^2}{(x^2)(x+h)^2}- \frac{x^2 + 2xh + h^2}{x^2( x+h)^2}}{h} \\ 
&= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{ \frac{ -2xh - h^2}{(x^2)(x+h)^2}}{h} \\
&= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{h(-2x - h)}{h(x^2)(x+h)^2} \\
&= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{(-2x - h)}{(x^2)(x+h)^2} \\
&= \frac{-2x}{x^4}
\end{align*}

So $\displaystyle f'(x) = \frac{-2}{x^3}$
hints:
The limit definition of the derivative is:

$\displaystyle \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x + h) - f(x)}{h}$
